title: The Antiquary - Volume 01
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Weel, weel, leddies," said the postmistress, "we'se sit down and crackabout it.Baby, bring ben the tea-waterMuckle obliged to ye for yourcookies, Mrs. Shortcakeand we'll steek the shop, and cry ben Baby, andtake a hand at the cartes till the gudeman comes hameand then we'lltry your braw veal sweetbread that ye were so kind as send me, Mrs.Heukbane."

title: The Heart of Mid-Lothian, Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Muckle better--muckle better--God bless you!--God bless you!--At no ratelet him gang till ye hear frae me," said Jeanie.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: By it Imarked the figure of Muckle John on his knees.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Muckle John, like some old priest ofDiana, flung up his arms to the heavens, and seemed to be invoking hisstrange gods.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I should master Muckle John as I had mastered him before.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Was it not the queerest fate that one whom I had met in my boyishscrapes should return after six years and many thousand miles to playonce more a major part in my life! The nameless general in the hillswas Muckle John Gib, once a mariner of Borrowstoneness, and some timeleader of the Sweet-Singers.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Then on the bank above me I saw the fellow who had run into me andhindered my catching Muckle John on dry land.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I lighted firm on the wood, and for a moment looked Muckle John in theface.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: ForMuckle John it was beyond doubt; not two men in the broad earth hadthat ungainly bend of neck.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The collision had cracked mytemper, and I had a mind to give Muckle John a lesson in civility.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: MuckleJohn had gone to the Plantations, and 'twas Muckle John or the devilthat was moving there in the half light.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: MuckleJohn had gone to the Plantations, and 'twas Muckle John or the devilthat was moving there in the half light.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Three weeks later I heard that Muckle John was destined for thePlantations in a ship of Mr. Barclay of Urie's, which traded to NewJersey.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: But I got no more of Muckle John's travels, for the door opened on thatinstant, and the gaoler appeared.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I was satisfied, from the look of Muckle John,that his dangerous fit was over, so I gave my voice for release.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I could not be fighting with Muckle Johnall the time, and I made no doubt that once his limbs were freed hewould try to kill me.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: So when Muckle John leaped to grab me, I dartedunder his arm, and he staggered half-way across the room.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: As he went on,I began to fancy that Muckle John's true place was with the Mussulmans,for he left not a stick of Christianity behind him.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: But sleep was impossible, for Muckle John got another fit of cursing Hestood up by the door with his eyes blazing like a wild-cat's, anddelivered what he called his "testimony."

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The women were given a countrycart to ride in, and the men, including Muckle John, had to run each bya trooper's leg.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Except for Muckle John, they were sopitifully feeble, a pack of humble, elderly folk, worn out with fastingand marching and ill weather.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The next I knew of it I was sprawling on theground with a dizzy head, and horses trampling around me, I had aglimpse of Muckle John with a pistol at his nose, and the sorrelcurveting and plunging in a panic.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Muckle John was onhis feet, half the clan had gone round to our rear, and in a second ortwo she would have been torn from the saddle.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: That was wellenough, but I saw Muckle John staggering to his feet, and I feareddesperately for his next move.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Muckle John let the thing fall into the moss, and plucked anotherweapon from his belt.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The word roused Muckle John to fury.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Perhaps Janet would have obeyed,but Muckle John, swift to prevent defection, took up the parable.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: A scream from the women brought Muckle John out of his rhapsodies.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The horse leaped the burn lightly, and beforeI could gather my wits was in the midst of the camp, where Muckle Johnwas vociferating to heaven.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Muckle John was so filled with hisvapourings that I could readily slip off down the burn and join thesouthern highway at the village of Linton.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: All but Muckle John himself.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: "Nay, but what seek ye?" cried Muckle John.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: It was the company whocalled themselves the Sweet-Singers, led by one Muckle John Gib, once amariner of Borrowstoneness-on-Forth.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The figureof Muckle John Gib will be familiar to the readers of Patrick Walker_.

title: Spare Hours
author: Brown, John
snippet: Being then young and keenbotanists, and full of the knowledge and love of Tweedside, having beenon every hill-top from Muckle Mendic to Hundleshope and the Lee Pen, andhaving fished every water from Tarth to the Leithen, we discovered earlyin spring that young Stewart, author of an excellent book on naturalhistory, a young man of great promise and early death, had found the_Buxbaumia aphylla_, a beautiful and odd-looking moss, west of Newbieheights, in the very month we were that moment in.

title: Memoirs of the life and writings of Thomas Chalmers...
author: Hanna, William
snippet: Went on horseback with a brother of Mr. Dalgleish's to scale the Muckle Bin, a large and lofty hill in the neighbourhood.

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: Being then young and keen botanists, and full of the knowledge and love of Tweedside, having been on every hill-top from Muckle Mendic to Hundleshope and the Lee Pen, and having fished every water from Tarth to the Leithen, we discovered  early in spring that young Stewart, author of an excellent book on natural history, a young man of great promise and early death, had found the Buxbaumia  aphylla, a beautiful and odd-looking moss, west of Newbie heights, in the very month we were that moment  in.

title: Lady Jean's Son. A novel
author: Tytler, Sarah
snippet: " Muckle wife, indeed ! That's her Grace ofDouglas.
